subject: Re: [junit] Testing philosophy question
msgSnippet: ... Rule of thumb is that each separate method should get a separate test. In this case, since the audience has a COBOL background, I would certainly recommend
messageBody:
On Thu, 20 Nov 2003, Chappell, Simon P wrote:

> I'm helping some of our COBOL programmers learn Java in their own time
> and once a week I do a small lunchtime "chalk and talk" session.
> Lately, I have started introducing JUnit, on the grounds that the
> sooner I teach them good habits, the more likely they are to stick
> with them. I'm using the java.lang.String class as the object being
> tested, so that we only have to worry about writing one class instead
> of two.
>
> My question is: When testing overloaded methods (String.indexOf() in
> this specific case), is it better for each overloaded method get it's
> own testXXX() method or is it ok to lump them all in the one test? I
> have them all in one test right now, on the grounds that the test is
> against the index feature, rather than the individual methods.

Rule of thumb is that each separate method should get a separate test.

In this case, since the audience has a COBOL background, I would
certainly recommend giving each overloaded method its own test method.
You need to get it clear in people's heads that overloaded methods are
in fact separate things.

In general there will be a number of assertions per test. You want to
test at boundary points, so there should be assertions on at least

* an empty string
* a case where the match is at the beginning
* a case where the match is at the end
* a case where there is no match

and probably one assertion on

* a case where the match is in the middle

Some people would put each assertion into a separate test method.
This is a quasi-religious issue for some. I would usually group
all of the assertions into one test method. Unless I was actually
implementing the indexOf() method, in which case I would probably not
be so brave ;-)
